Overview

The packageSkeletonForR repo contains a package skeleton suitable for quickly setting up an R package with an associated GitHub website, all hosted in your own repo on GitHub. The bulk of the work is in customizing the package (e.g., changing the name of the package to your something you want to call it). This repo attempts to guide you through the process of setting this up. Prerequisite knowlege for using this includes:

  • Knowing the basics of GitHub including cloning a repo, making a commit to a repo, pushing changes to a repo.
  • Knowing the basics of what an R package is. Many people don't produce R packages because they don't think they have anything worthy to put into a package. Instead of thinking about making a package that is useful for someone else, think of making a package that is useful for what you do, for example:
    • Useful little data cleaning functions that may apply to data that you normally work with.
    • Useful wrapper functions that use functions from base R and other packages that provide output in a way that you best work with.
    • And don't be afraid to steal (with attribution, of course) other functions and put them into your package (with possible customizations). This is open source, you know!

The following steps are meant to help you get set up:

Step 0: Make sure you have the basics installed

You'll need to have software installed and access to GitHub to make all of this work.

  • Have R >= 4.0 installed.
  • Make sure you have a GitHub account with a username and password
  • You'll need to install several R packages to make all of this work:
    • devtools: install.packages("devtools")
    • packagePages: devtools::install_github("centerforassessment/packagePages")
    • centerPackageTemplate: devtools::install_github("centerforassessment/centerPackageTemplate")

Step 1: Clone the GitHub repository

The contents of this repo need to be cloned to your local computer/device. This is done by cloning the repo. Don't fork the repo as you won't be contributing to this package skeleton but instead will be using this as a starting point to create your own R package/GitHub repo.

I love feedback and am happy to answer questions. Feel free to clone and make a pull request with the specifications for other languages.
